dt: {bc}to state or do over again or repeatedly sometimes with wearying effect

quotes.t: "And are you glad to see me?" asked she, {qword}reiterating{/qword} her former question, and pleased to detect the faint dawn of a smile.

Judge Douglas has again, for, I believe, the fifth time, if not the seventh, in my presence, {qword}reiterated{/qword} his charge of a conspiracy or combination between the National Democrats and Republicans.
He iterates and {qword}reiterates{/qword} that his lab likewise provided the French with many biological tools and samples, as well as significant technical guidance …
Easy victories bring little satisfaction; repeated failures encourage {qword}reiterated{/qword} effort, to the moment of ultimate gratification or ultimate resignation.

et: Middle English, from Latin {it}reiteratus{/it}, past participle of {it}reiterare{/it} to repeat, from {it}re-{/it} + {it}iterare{/it} to iterate
shortdef: to state or do over again or repeatedly sometimes with wearying effect
